content:
Hello, I currently try to Lean 4, mostly by studying "Theorem Proving in Lean 4" but I'd like to also look at real-world examples in parallel. But mathlib4 seems highly interdependent, so I don't really know where to start. Hence two questions:

  • Are there beginner friendly "entry points" to mathlib4, with not too many dependencies?

  • Is it possible to "compile" a given file so that all dependencies are included directly in the file, i.e. creating a standalone file? From what I understand, .olean files do something similar, but not in a human readable format. So is it maybe possible to compile a human readable .olean file?

Thanks!

Is it possible to "compile" a given file so that all dependencies are included directly in the file, i.e. creating a standalone file?

For what purpose? For any remotely non-trivial result this is likely to be tens of thousands of lines
Perhaps it helps to know that if you open any file in VSCode, you can Ctrl+click on names to jump to where they're defined.
I thought it would help me to decide which files are worthwhile to study, when I see that one file has 100 lines of dependencies and another has 10k. But will check out the VSCode extension, thanks!

It's very rare to need to follow the dependencies all the way to the bottom. A good place to start would be something (simple!) that you know the mathematics of well; if you share a bit about your background, the community might be able to suggest some good places to start
my background is just undergraduate stuff plus some set theory, measure theory, little bit of category theory... i think i'll start with some data definitions like Data/Finset!
Klaus Gy has marked this topic as resolved.
